chapter.title: API compatibility definition
chapter.para: This chapter presents the formal definition of what is considered to be in the PLplot library API. The PLplot developers commit to introduce backwards compatibilities as few as possible, such that stability across releases is practically guaranteed. However, in the eventuality that the interface or the behavior of any function in the API changes, then the library soname will be changed (in systems that support versioned shared libraries).

sect1.title: What is in the API?
sect1.para: The formal definition of the PLplot C API is everything that is defined in the include file plplot.h. This includes all the function prototypes, the defined structures and the semantics of the constants. sect1.title: Regression test for backwards compatibility
sect1.para: Since PLplot is developed by so many people, the task of checking for backwards compatiblity of the library is very hard. As for the 5.3.1 release, we do not have any rigorous regression test for check whether the library is really backwards compatible.

However, here are some rules to be followed by the Release Manager prior to releasing a new version of PLplot:
Check if there are any changes in plplot.h. If no prototype is changed, then the chances are high that no backwards compatibilities have been introduced. If new functions has been added, then the library soname will be kept, although the libtool version string in configure.ac must be changed from x:y:z to (x+1):0:(z+1). See the libtool manual for details.
A necessary, but not sufficient test consists of the following: first, install the previous released version of PLplot in the system and compile all the examples examples/c/x??c.. After that, install the to-be-released version of PLplot and try to run the examples. If they either link and run incorrectly, then backwards compatibilities have been added and the version string should be upgraded from x:y:z to (x+1):0:0.
